4f27d37bf5ad4c99ad9d2a0f1d13db7a (21:52): anyone seen that before?
596edd8f06f4d3bddb2964385e0385e0 (21:52): any designers ever hangout here?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (21:52): in fact, those are largely for the CSS shorthand use
e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d (21:57): Hi guys, do you think that parsing CSS/HTML with PHP needs less resources than with JS?
58649878b7e5f1ee39e9034b8cd6ae5d (21:59): e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d: Certainly it uses _different_ resources.
58649878b7e5f1ee39e9034b8cd6ae5d (21:59): e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d: PHP is server side, JS is client side, so by using JS you're offloading it to the end user.
58649878b7e5f1ee39e9034b8cd6ae5d (22:00): e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d: On the other hand, you're also making your pages more of a resource hog, but nobody seems to care about that, these days.
e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d (22:01): 58649878b7e5f1ee39e9034b8cd6ae5d: So for bigger projects it's better to move as much work as possible on client?
4f27d37bf5ad4c99ad9d2a0f1d13db7a (22:06): the client already has so much CSS transition rendering to do -.-
e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d (22:06): well, of course it's best to do as least work as possible
e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d (22:06): on both sides
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (22:26): e4d6e7f4fcaff24a1d65b9d2de57f23d: PHP is not godo for parsing
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (22:26): not good
